intro: Hydrobryum chompuense, commonly known as the Chompúns River moss, is a rare aquatic plant native to the Andean region of South America. It thrives in slow-moving freshwater streams and rivers, typically in shaded, nutrient-rich environments. The plant has delicate, ribbon-like leaves that form dense mats on the substrate, contributing to water filtration and habitat creation for microorganisms. Its reproductive structures, called sporophytes, develop on the leaf surfaces and release spores into the water. Due to habitat degradation, Hydrobryum chompuense is considered endangered and is of particular interest to botanists studying aquatic plant ecology.
